key_issues: Trademarks infringement is alleged by the plaintiff, AIWA CO. LTD., against the defendants, AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED & ORS., for using a deceptively similar mark 'AIVVA'.
The plaintiff claims to have worldwide trademark registrations in respect of its mark 'AIWA' and its formative marks, and has acquired tremendous reputation and goodwill throughout the world.
The use of the mark 'AIVVA' by the defendants is claimed to be identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademarks, and may cause confusion among customers.
The plaintiff has sought a permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from using the mark 'AIVVA' or any other mark that may be identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademarks.
An ex parte ad interim injunction was granted by the Court in favor of the plaintiff, restraining the defendants from using the impugned marks.
The defendants' use of the mark 'AIVVA' is also alleged to constitute passing off, as it may deceive customers into believing that the defendants' products are associated with the plaintiff.
The plaintiff has claimed that the defendants have copied the stylized version of the plaintiff's mark, which is a serious infringement of the plaintiff's trademark rights.
The registration of the mark 'AIVVA' by the defendants is alleged to be an attempt to pass off their products as those of the plaintiff.
The plaintiff has sought ancillary reliefs, including damages and costs, in addition to the permanent injunction.
The Court has to determine whether the defendants' use of the mark 'AIVVA' constitutes an infringement of the plaintiff's trademark rights and whether the plaintiff is entitled to the reliefs sought.

**Case Summary: AIWA Co. Ltd. vs. AIVVA Enterprises Private Limited & Ors.**

**Background:**
The plaintiff, AIWA Co. Ltd., a Japanese company, is the registered proprietor of the trademark "AIWA" in various classes, including Class 9 (televisions and audio equipment). The defendants, AIVVA Enterprises Private Limited and others, are allegedly using the mark "AIVVA" and its stylized version, which is deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA". The plaintiff claims that the defendants' actions amount to trademark infringement and passing off.

**Legal Issues:**
The legal issues in this case involve trademark infringement and passing off under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC). The plaintiff seeks a permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from using the mark "AIVVA" or any other mark that is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA".

**Arguments:**
The plaintiff argues that:

1. The defendants' use of the mark "AIVVA" is deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA", which is a well-known mark worldwide.
2. The defendants have copied the stylized version of the plaintiff's mark, which is a clear indication of intent to pass off their goods as those of the plaintiff.
3. The defendants' actions have caused and are likely to cause confusion among consumers, amounting to passing off.

The defendants' arguments are not explicitly stated in the provided pages, but it can be inferred that they may argue that their mark "AIVVA" is not deceptively similar to the plaintiff's mark "AIWA" or that they have not intended to pass off their goods as those of the plaintiff.

**Court Findings:**
The court, after considering the plaintiff's application, granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiff, restraining the defendants from using the mark "AIVVA" or any other mark that is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA". The court found that the defendants' use of the mark "AIVVA" was deceptively similar to the plaintiff's mark and that the defendants had copied the stylized version of the plaintiff's mark.

**Decision:**
The court's decision is to grant a permanent injunction to the plaintiff, restraining the defendants from using the mark "AIVVA" or any other mark that is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA". The court's order includes the following terms:

1. The defendants are restrained from using the mark "AIVVA" or any other mark that is identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA".
2. The defendants are restrained from using the mark "AIVVA" or any other mark that is deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA" as a trademark or part of a trademark, a corporate name/trade name, a domain name or part of a domain name, an email address or part of an email address, or in any manner whatsoever in relation to their goods/services that are similar to those of the plaintiff.

The court's decision is based on the finding that the defendants' use of the mark "AIVVA" is deceptively similar to the plaintiff's trademark "AIWA" and that the defendants have intended to pass off their goods as those of the plaintiff.

cannot be contended that the aforesaid notice was sent with the knowledge
and consent of the plaintiff company. It was for the defendants to show that
there was a connection between the said entity and the plaintiff company or
that the plaintiff company was aware of the aforesaid legal notice.

LTD., filed a complaint against the defendants, AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED, and others. The court reserved judgment on December 16, 2022, and delivered it on January 5, 2023.

The plaintiff, a Japanese company, is the registered proprietor of the trademark "AIWA" in various classes, including Class 9 for televisions and audio equipment. The defendant, AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED, was using the mark "AIVVA" and a stylized version of it, which the plaintiff alleged was a infringement of its trademark.

The plaintiff's trademark "AIWA" has been included in the list of well-known marks maintained by the Trademark Registry since 2007. The plaintiff holds worldwide trademark registrations in respect of its mark "AIWA" and its formative marks. The plaintiff became aware of the defendant's use of the mark "AIVVA" in August 2022 and filed an application for an ex parte ad interim injunction.

The court considered the applications filed by the plaintiff under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, and the applications filed by the defendants. The judgment, delivered by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, dispose of the applications and provides the court's decision on the matter. (Source: PDF document "AIWA CO. LTD. VS. According to the PDF document "AIWA CO. LTD. VS. AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED & OR" (2023/DHC/000041), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard a case between Aiwa Co. Ltd. (plaintiff) and Aivva Enterprises Private Limited (defendant). The plaintiff claimed trademark infringement and passing off by the defendant's use of the mark "AIVVA", which is allegedly deceptively similar to the plaintiff's "AIWA" mark.

The court granted an ex-parte ad interim injunction on September 2, 2022, restraining the defendants from using the "AIVVA" mark or any other mark identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiff's "AIWA" mark. The defendants were also directed to take down their webpage from the e-commerce platform IndiaMART.

The defendants filed an application (I.A.16402/2022) against the injunction order, arguing that the plaintiff was aware of their use of the "AIVVA" mark since August 2020, but delayed approaching the court. The defendants also claimed that the plaintiff had knowledge of their trademark registrations in 2015.

The court reserved judgment on December 16, 2022, and delivered it on January 5, 2023. The case involves claims of trademark infringement, passing off, and seeks permanent injunction, as well as other ancillary reliefs. The PDF document provides details of the legal proceedings, including submissions, arguments, and court decisions. (Source: PDF document "AIWA CO. LTD. VS. The judgment was reserved on December 16, 2022, and delivered on January 5, 2023. The plaintiff, AIWA CO. LTD., is represented by Ms. Anuradha Salhotra. 

The defendants, AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED, argue that no written authorization is required for using the trademark 'AIVVA', citing the Supreme Court judgment in Cycle Corporation of India Ltd. v. T.I. Raleigh Industries Pvt. Ltd. They also claim that they have been selling TVs under the mark 'AIVVA' since 2016, providing invoices as evidence.

The plaintiff counters that they conducted a search of the Trademark Registry before filing the suit and found no authorization for the defendants to use the trademark 'AIWA'. The plaintiff also argues that the defendants' use of the trademark 'AIVVA' is an attempt to ride on the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiff's trademark 'AIWA'. The plaintiff disputes the defendants' claim that they have a license to use the trademark, citing the lack of written agreement between the defendants and Mr. Ajjaay Advani, who allegedly permitted the use of the trademark. Additionally, the court notes that Mr. Ajjaay Advani is not a director or shareholder of the defendant companies, and there is no license or document assigning the mark 'AIVVA' to the defendants. The court's decision was delivered on January 5, 2023, in the case CS(COMM) 606/2022. (Source: PDF "11. AIWA CO. LTD. VS. AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED & OR.pdf", page 10)

According to the PDF document "11. AIWA CO. LTD. VS. AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED & OR.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi delivered a judgment on January 5, 2023, in the case of CS(COMM) 606/2022. The plaintiff, AIWA CO. LTD., had filed a suit against the defendants, AIVVA ENTERPRISES PRIVATE LIMITED, for selling TVs that infringe on the plaintiff's trademarks. 

The court found that the defendants were using the trademark "AIVVA" which is phonetically similar to the plaintiff's mark "AIWA". The plaintiff had acquired enormous goodwill and reputation worldwide due to the publicity and long use of its mark. The court held that the defendants' use of the impugned mark was prima facie dishonest and an attempt to ride on the goodwill and reputation of the plaintiff's mark.

The court confirmed the interim order dated September 2, 2022, which injuncted the defendants from using the impugned trademark until the final adjudication of the suit. The court also dismissed I.A. 16402/2022 and allowed I.A. 14162/2022. The next hearing is scheduled for April 20, 2023. The judgment was delivered by AMIT BANSAL, J. on January 5, 2023. The PDF document provides detailed information about the legal proceedings, facts, arguments, and decisions made by the court. (Source: 11. AIWA CO. LTD. VS.
